items.title: What is an API? A Quick Explanation
items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description: Quick Concept: What Is An API? What Is A REST API?

>

There are things that are simply hard to explain and the concept of an API falls into that category like a ring on a finger.

Technically speaking an API is an acronym for Application Programming Interface; it has a set of functions and protocols designed to allow two services to communicate with each other.

In normal terms an API is just a middleman that tells you what he can, and is allowed to about another service. When you call your bank’s customer service you need to validate your identity and then you can ask for certain things like your current balance or about a new product, but if you ask about another person’s account the rep will politely decline since you can’t have access.

In the example above the API would be the customer service rep and the two services would be the bank and you.

As you can tell it is really just very abstract since it is not a program with a graphic interface you can use but rather a structured middleware designed to provide and control access to information. You wouldn’t want anyone just having access to your database, right?

Since an API can bring you the information you want you can have many different APIs from many services and use them to build your projects much quicker.

For example: if you want to build an app that gets you the Top 10 Pop music songs in your country and is always up-to-date you can use Spotify’s API and that’s it. Just ask the API for the information and you just worry about building the front end!

There are many different types of APIs but the most common use is for web applications and the giant there would be the REST API.

REST API

>

It is very simple to use. You can make a request with a url like if you were typing a website’s address. As a matter of fact you can actually make requests using your browser and see the data it returns!

REST APIs use the GET, POST, PUT and DELETE methods found in HTTP. This is why you’re able to make requests using your browser.

Also, the format of the data it returns is very simple to read and use. You can receive the data in JSON, CSV, or RSS formats. The most commonly used one of the three is JSON since most programming languages have a god JSON interpreter.

A simple example of a REST api usage would be the following:

  • Type

>https://api.github.com/users/torvalds in your browser.
  • Received JSON response:

>

As you can see you can make a simple request to GitHub’s public API and get data from a user account. In this case it is the legend himself: Linus Torvalds.

This is just a basic introduction to the concept of an API and what you can do with it.

You can contact me on twitter if you have any questions or suggestions, have a good one!

S.

items.title: How To Setup And Use SSH For Remote Connections
items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description:
>

If you want to handle remote servers or maybe you just want to set up a connection to your local computer this is your spot. If you keep reading you will know enough about SSH to establish a secure connection to a remote machine.

This can be useful for your home computer in case you forgot something while you’re away and need to connect to it to retrieve it.

I will show you in a few steps how to set up an SSH connection through your terminal. The process is quite simple but first let me set YOU up with the basics.

What you need:

  • Your favorite Shell.
  • Make sure you have SSH installed, it comes by default on Linux and MacOS systems. If not just run the following commands:
sudo apt-get install openssh-server
sudo systemctl enable ssh
sudo systemctl start ssh

What is SSH?

>

Simply put, Secure Shell is a protocol designed to transfer data between a client and a server (two computers basically) over an untrusted network.

The way SSH works is it encrypts the connection using a pair of keys and the server, which is the computer you would connect to, is usually waiting for an SSH connection on Port 22.

Now let’s see how to create the key pair and then connect:

How to create an SSH-key pair:

1) Type ssh-keygen -t rsa in your shell. This command will create the keys with the rsa version 2 protocol (recommended).

2) You will be asked for a location. If you decide to enter one manually then that will be the pair’s location, if you leave the default one it will be inside the .ssh hidden folder in your home directory.

>

3) Now you will be prompted for a password. If you enter one you will be asked for it every time you use the key, this works for added security. If you don’t want a password just press enter and continue without one.

>

4) There is no 4! That’s it! Your keys have been saved in the specified folder and you will see something weird like this:

>

As you may have noticed from the image in point #3 two files were created. One file ends with the ‘.pub’ extension and the other one doesn’t.

The file that ends with ‘.pub’ is your public key. This key needs to be in the computer you want to connect to (the server) inside a file called authorized_keys . You can accomplish this with the following command:

ssh-copy-id username@ip

For example in my case to send the key to my computer it would be:

ssh-copy-id sergiop@132.132.132.132

If you have MacOS there’s a chance you don’t have ssh-copy-id installed, in that case you can install it using brew install ssh-copy-id.

The file that has no extension is your private key. You must cherish it, save it, take care of it. There is only one and you can’t generate another one if you lose it so I recommend you send it to your email or something like that.

Remember both keys have the same name the only difference is one ends with ‘.pub’ and the other one doesn’t.

How to connect to a remote machine using SSH:

>

For this final trick I would like you to use the following command:

ssh -i ~/private/key/location remote_username@remote_ip

This command uses the -i flag for you to specify where the private key is located. Remember where it is? Now type its location there. Where it says username type the one you are going to connect as and then type the remote machine’s ip address after the ‘@’ symbol. Just like we did earlier to transfer the key.

You will be asked if you’re sure you want to continue connecting since the ‘authenticity of host can’t be established’. Type ‘yes’ and hit Enter. This is just because this is your first time connecting to that machine.

Now you will be asked to enter a password if you set one with the key or if the user you’re connecting to has one set up.

Once you successfully do it you will see something like this:

>
  • Note: it doesn’t have to look exactly like this; your configuration and specs will vary. The important thing is you can tell you are now connected to a remote machine.

That’s it! It is a very useful, simple and secure way to manage your remote connections.

I hope you enjoyed this brief tutorial.

Some resources:
>How to Enable SSH on Ubuntu 18.04
>How To Set Up SSH Keys | DigitalOcean
>What is Secure Shell (SSH) and How Does it Work?
>Set up SSH public-key authentication to connect to a remote system
>Ubuntu Linux install OpenSSH server - nixCraft

items.title: 5 Health Tips For Programmers
items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description:
>

There is no shortcut and no magic tricks.

The only way around is through and this might help you in the long run. No, it is not easy but neither is programming and you’re already doing that!

1) WORKOUT/SPORTS

>

As obvious as this might seem it has to be mentioned.

When it comes to physical activity we are not well known for being the most athletic kind of people. This is a direct consequence of spending countless hours sitting in front of the computer, carelessly eating some snacks to keep working. Taking breaks is important but being active in them is also important!

Let me reassure you that after a hard coding session what you need the most is distraction. When you are pushing your limits both physically and mentally you are creating balance and letting off steam.

Working out (in any way you like) can help you reduce stress and anxiety, improve your state of mind, improve your confidence and keep you healthy in your everyday life!

2) COUNT CALORIES (IIFYM)

>

Losing weight and/or gaining weight has a lot of factors that go around it but for the most part it’s a game of calories in — calories out and fitting the rest of your macro-nutrients in your daily caloric intake.

There is a great method, I don’t like to call it a diet since people associate them with starving themselves, called I.I.F.Y.M (If It Fits Your Macros). This is based on the science that each person has a certain nutrient intake every day that they can manipulate it to maintain, lose, or gain weight.

The way this method works is simple: you have your macro-nutrient quota and it’s up to you how you spend it. You can eat a McDonalds burger or an icecream with absolutely no guilt if it fits your macros ;)

Count your daily intake by using an app called MyFitness Pal (available on all platforms). Do this a couple of days and see what you average. Then, depending on the objective you have start controlling your caloric and nutrient intake (the app gives you all that info). If for example you want to lose weight start a caloric deficit (start with around 300 calories less) and see how it goes for a week.

This is the best way to control your weight that I know of, it’s kind of tedious to be entering your meal info on the app daily but it’s also worth it!

3) GOOD POSTURE

>

We’re told time and time again to sit up straight, and it’s annoying! But it’s all for good reasons. Bad posture can affect your health in all sorts of ways.

A bad posture while in front of the computer can give you back, neck and shoulder pain. It can also cause poor circulation giving you varicose veins, cause poor digestion by compressing your abdominal organs, misaligned spine and other nasty things.

It is very important for you to do your best and be conscious of the way you sit down. This will help you correct your posture when you catch yourself slouching too much, you don’t want to end up like her:

>

Her name is Emma and she is a representation scientists have made of how a middle aged woman with all sorts of health issues (derived from a desk job in front of a computer) would look like.

With the three things I mentioned above you can avoid many of the things afflicting Emma like that horrible hunch or the swollen wrists due to carpal tunnel syndrome.

4) TAKE BREAKS

>

Life is all about perspectives, the way you see the world shapes it for you.

After spending countless hours coding and trying to fix a bug your vision can become blurry, your eyes are tired from looking at the screen and your head feels like it’s about to blow. Somehow you still can’t let this go. This is personal now. The bug must be hunted down.

Then comes a team mate just chilling, sipping a nice hot coffee he just made for himself, and asks you “What’s wrong?” so you tell him and after looking at your screen for two seconds he tells you you have an extra bracket at the end of your code. You feel stupid now, how could that happen?

Perspective! You need to take breaks, this is fundamental in your life. When things are starting to get out of hand just take a step back, breathe, do something else entirely for a little bit so you can rest your mind and then come back to try again.

Once rested you can be sure that you’ll see things differently and you are more likely to spot or figure out what you need to do.

5) CIRCADIAN RITHM

>

This one sounds like the title of a music album.

The circadian rithm is like your body’s natural clock. Has it happened to you that when a holiday comes you think “I’m going to sleep untill 12:00 pm!” but then you wake up by yourself at 6:00 am? Well, that is your internal alarm called the circadian rithm.

We all have different rithms. You can get hungry at different times than your teammates, maybe feel energized at night all the time, feel drowsy at a certain moment during the day or even go to the bathroom at the same time every day. This is all because of how your body’s processes are scheduled and keeping these processes in check is always a good idea.

The best way you can keep your rithm in check is by controlling your sleep schedule and not letting it get out of hand very often. While you do this you will control and know when you are most productive during the day, when you have the most energy so you can workout, when you go to the bathroom so you don’t catch any foul bowel movements, and even when you can take breaks and just relax your mind.

You can improve several aspects of your life little by little by doing this while being self-aware and disciplined.

Keep in mind these are all suggestions and should be taken as such. My personal advice in no way is meant to be definitive or is implying there is only one way to do these things. I hope you enjoyed reading through and can take something valuable from this.

items.title: Reasons why you need to learn Dart + Flutter in 2020
items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description:
>

There are way too many programming languages and infinite use-cases for each one of them, every day developers are coming up with something new and we need to keep up with the flow.

Both of these technologies are relatively new when you compare them to the most popular languages and frameworks, they have been look over for some years now but I would consider this combo to be ahead of its time like if you sold an electric car in 1995.

Let me tell you why:

What is Dart?

>

Let’s kick this off by explaining some qualities of Dart.

First, it is developed by Google and it launched in 2011. Google uses Dart to develop many of its main applications including Ads which as you can imagine must require quite a solid build.

Dart is very flexible on the way it is compiled and executed, it is in fact the only programming language capable of compiling JIT (Just In Time — used during development) and AOT (Ahead Of Time — used when the app is released), it can also be compiled to Javascript in order to be ran by browsers or straight to native code. This means its execution is fast.

Thanks to its versatility Dart can be used for client or server-side development. The syntax looks like ‘C’ meaning it is a statically typed so this provides more certainty on the types of values you are passing on, but it is also meant to be used in OOP, if you have a background in C you’ll pick it up quick. Dart also shares some similarities with Javascript like the use of arrow and asynchronous functions.

Let’s not forget about ‘hot reload’.

You can test your code like if it was an html and you were refreshing the page to see the changes. Yes, it is that easy.

Dart has been slept on by the dev community for too long but I think its time is coming with the mobile-first principle that is gaining such massive momentum. It runs fast on all platforms and is easy to pick up and learn by programmers.

Check it out here:

>Dart programming language

Now, you might think: “but what type of frameworks may I use with it? I already use React Native for cross-platform development.”

Here comes Flutter!

What is Flutter?

>

Flutter is an app SDK (Software Development Kit) built to help you make fast, stable apps for your mobile device (any of them!) or your desktop. It also has a framework with a bunch of widgets and design elements to help you build a beautiful front quicker than Usain Bolt running a 100m dash.

With a single codebase you will be able to deploy beautiful apps for both iOS and Android. We’re living in a mobile-first world so this is massive nowadays, people are more likely to have a smartphone than a computer.

The documentation is solid. Google has your back on bothe the programming language and the framework so you can be sure to find a lot of it.

The community is growing, slowly, but steadily and even though it is not the size of a Python or Javascript community you can still find plenty of websites where other developers exchange ideas and Widgets they have built to help you in your future builds. This means you can hop on the train soon and maybe even be the founder of your local community!

Flutter is supported in Android Studio and Visual Studio Code. This is a must for every major framework today since specially VS Code is one of the most used code editors for development and those plugins it has are gold.

“But you haven’t said anything about React Native.”

Remember Dart’s flexibility to compile and execute code?

When it comes to React Native’s capability to build cross-platform applications remember that it needs something that is commonly called the Javascript Bridge. This bridge is used to communicate with native modules and results in poorer performance. Dart code, on the other hand, is compiled straight to machine/native code.

>

Another thing you might like in Flutter better than React is the fact that UI design and components are much easier to implement and manipulate for them to work with any device.

To conclude, so I don’t take much more of your time I will leave you with some resources you can check out to dig more information about this wonder-couple:
>Why Flutter Uses Dart | Hacker Noon
>What makes Dart an easy, scalable, multi-purpose programming language
>What is Flutter and Why You Should Learn It in 2020
>Flutter vs React Native: A Developer's Perspective

This guide will fit your needs perfectly as I will show you how to easily build and deploy a site without any large quantities of money or anything like that. Get ready to build something this quarantine like this fierce lego lady is.

I will teach you where to get the template (because there is no need to reinvent the wheel), how to customize it, how the custom domains work, and finally how to upload your project to the web for the world to see. Take into account that there are a myriad of different alternatives different than the ones I’m going to show you here, each with its pros and cons, but this is just the starting point for you to begin your web journey and get the hype up.

First of all, you might be wondering what do I mean by a “static site”. A static site is just a website whose content doesn’t change often and is mainly just up for informational purposes. An example of this would be something like a portfolio site that doesn’t get updated so often or a law firm’s site that just displays information on their services and some other general data, maybe a contact form.

Now let’s got straight to the point:

STEP I: create a GitHub account.

GitHub is basically a social network for developers (like Behance is for creatives and artists to display their work). It is very easy to use and we will need this later on in order to host our source code.

>Click here to go to the website.

Github is a social network that uses the Git version control system. This means that basically you can save an article that you wrote here, then update the file because you forgot to add something but oh it turns out the way it was before was actually better! Don’t worry in this case thanks to the version control you will be able to go back to a previous version where everything was good, like time travel.

Learning how to properly use Git will do wonders for you and save you a lot of headaches once you start getting deeper into programming but for now we’ll just use it to link the account to Netlify’s service.

STEP II: create a Netlify account.

>

Netlify is a modern platform designed to help you host your sites easier. This helps you save money in unnecessary hosting services if you just want to build a static site and not something that requires a massive backend development like a social network.

>Click here to go to the website.

Go to the link I just provided and click on ‘Get Started For Free’. Now you will be asked to log-in with a service of your choice, you will be given several options but guess which one you need to choose. That’s right, Github. After you selected it the system will prompt you to authorize Netlify -some backend magic happens here with OAuth security methods- and finally your account will be set.

>

Yes, it’s that simple, github will facilitate your life in many ways.

STEP III: Downoad Publii CMS

>

A Control Management System or better known as a CMS is a software that will allow you to build and edit web pages in this case with little to no technical knowledge. There are many other use cases and many different types of CMS tools for all sorts of thing but in this case we will keep our eyes on the web development side and use a CMS called ‘Publii’.

Publii is an open source CMS developed by a guy named Bob Mitro that has been around in the web development world for a while now. This is not his first rodeo and it shows.

Publii is designed to be used from your desktop so you have the advantage of being able to test your modifications offline, it will give you very fast loading speeds due to the lack of unnecessary bloating in the websites and it is a perfect start for your blogging journey.

Now, you might be thinking: why would I use this instead of Wordpress? While Wordpress is the most widely used CMS in the market and it has a million features the reality is you need to spend more money, have greater technical knowledge, it is harder to handle and unless you want a very big website with lots of dynamic functions that require the use of some specific plugins it is not necessary. So let’s get started with the beautiful Publii!

>First go to this site.

Here you will be presented with some options for the type of download you want. Select the one that corresponds to your operating system and execute the installer.

After the installer is done open up Publii, you should have a link in your desktop.

Now you will get a screen prompting you to create a new site. Yes, you are very close. Can you feel it?

>

Type a name you want for your site. This is the name that will show up in the tab on your browser when you open it up. Now type your name in the author section, and selet any color and any logo, these will just be useful to recognize which site is which since you are able to handle multiple sites at once with this beautiful piece of software.

After you are done press ‘create website’ and voilá you have generated your first site! But there are still some steps you need to take in order to put it online; in case you want to have a preview click on the option that says ‘preview your changes’ in the lower-right part of the Publii interface.

STEP IV: Connect Netlify and Publii

>

Now comes the time to join both worlds in perfect harmony.

First, open up your Netlify account and you will be on the ‘Sites’ section of your profile. You will need to create one so then Publii can override the draft you created with the one you really want to upload. Don’t worry you won’t have to code anything just download a file and then drag and drop it.

In

>THIS page you will find a bunch of free themes that are all beautiful and fast, it’s the official site for Publii themes so you can’t go wrong with ay of them but be careful since there are about 3 or 4 of those that are paid and the rest are free. Let’s grab the one that looks like a technology blog; for speed’s sake this is the direct link to download it:

>TECH BLOG TEMPLATE.

Now unzip the file and drag and drop the folder in your browser inside the corresponding area. Scroll down a bit and you’ll see it (remember this is in the ‘Sites’ section):

>

A new screen will show up that looks like this:

>

There are a lot of things but the main is that your site has been given a random name like the one you see in the image that starts with “nervous” and right below there are two options, click the one that says ‘Site Settings’.

Scroll down a bit and this information will be displayed to you:

>

This is most of the information you need. Now open up Publii and click on where it says ‘Server’ on the left side of the interface.

Select the option that says ‘Netlify’:

>

There are a bunch of fields you need to enter in order to properly link up Netlify and Publii. This will allow you to establish an authorized connection and then you may begin customizing your site.

In ‘Domain’ click the dropdown menu and select the ‘https://’ option. Https is a secure communication protocol which is what shows the little lock symbol when you enter a webpage. This will give your site a secure status so browsers don’t give you any trouble and people will trust it more. If you want to learn more about how the web works in the background visit my previous blog:
>What happens when you surf the web?

>

Right next to this dropdown menu you need to copy and paste your site’s name. If you want you can change it first by pressing the ‘Change site name’ option in that same screen.

Leave Netlify as the selected Protocol.

The ‘Site ID’ is the ‘API ID’; find in the Netlify page then just copy and paste it in the Site ID field.

Finally, we need to generate an access token for the Netlify account to conect to Publii. You see, you need to grant Publii permissions to both your site and your account so this is the last step in the link-up process.

Go to Netlify and in the top-right corner you’ll see a circle with your profile image on it. Click it and then select ‘User Settings’. Once the settings page opens up click on ‘Applications’ on the left side of the page.

You should now see something like this:

>

Select New Access Token, then type a name for the token. The name is just something for you to recognize what you made that token for in case you forget.

>

Copy the token and paste it in the ‘Netlify Token’ field of Publii.

Now save the changes and click ‘Test Connection’. A green banner should now appear making it clear you have established a successful connection so to finalize the syncing process click on the ‘Sync Your Website’ button that appears in the lower-left side of the screen.

Congratulations! You have successfully linked Netlify and Publii. Click on ‘Preview Your Changes’ to see how your site looks at the moment.

STEP V: Customize theme.

>

Publii has a really simple way to change the theme of your site. Remember the one we downloaded previously? Let’s use that one to illustrate the example.

First, in the top-right corner of Publii you’ll see three dots, one on top of the other. Click them and select ‘Global Settings’.

Then, scroll down and see the ‘Sites Location’. Go to that folder and unzip the theme you just downloaded there. You will also see the default ‘simple’ theme so you know how you need to put it.

Lastly, close Publii and then reopen it, go to the settings option and right beside where it says current theme you’ll find a drop-down menu that has the newly added option. Just select that option (Technews) then click save & preview to see it in action.

>

**REMEMBER: in order to save any changes you make on Publii to your website you need to save and then upload the changes to Netlify. Do this by clicking ‘Sync your website’ in the lower-left corner!**

Now comes the moment you have been waiting for, your site is up and you just need to play with Publii a little to understand how it works. In case you want to delete everything and start over just go to settings and click ‘Delete website’. Then repeat the process.

This program is very intuitive and will get you rolling on the web development world. There is so much more you can do if you are willing to get your hands dirty with code that you will be overwhelmed with the options that are available and the technologies you can learn on the way.

As a final note keep in mind that in order to change the domain name (the name of your site) to something you want like ‘example.com’ instead of having ‘example.netlify.com’ you need to purchase the domain name. Netlify gives you the option to do this straight on their website or you can do it independently on any other site like GoDaddy, NameCheap, Google domains, etc etc. There are always plenty of options when it comes to technology.

I hope you have found this guide useful and if you have any questions don’t hesitate to contact me on any social network!

items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description:
>opentechdiary

(Internet<->Things)

I remember the first time I saw glimpses of a connected world. I had just broken my arm and I was in the hospital with my parents waiting for my x-ray results, my mom pulls out this tiny thing — a Siemens Mobile phone — and says: “Check this out”, then she proceeds to write a text message and sends it to my dad’s phone. When he pulled out another phone and showed me the message I was shocked (then I spent all her texts playing with the phone).

Society and technology have come a long way since then and now pretty much anything you can think of can be connected in some shape or form to this wonderful thing called the internet. In fact, the internet itself is a limitless connection of networks that talk to each other by some rules that were established a while back known as protocols.

Along with many other impactful concepts like globalization in world politics came some other new ones like IoT (Internet of Things). But what exactly is this?

The Internet of Things refers to the way technology has advanced up to the point where now even the clothes or shoes you wear can be connected to your mobile phone, and the phone connected to the internet so you can check out other people’s statistics and see if you ran your half-marathon faster than the average runner.

Amazing, right? Now think about this so you can put it more into perspective and appreciate the advancements we have made a little more: over the last TWO years 90% of the data that currently exists (including all data from the past) was generated. This is huge, there is a lot to handle here and we are more powerful than we’ve ever been thanks to the internet.

>

If you take a closer look at the statistics for internet usage your mind will be blown, but this is just the beginning, remember the internet as we know it and use it nowadays only started to kick in in the 90’s when the World Wide Web was invented!

More information is available now at our fingertips than ever before, we have the combined knowledge of the world in our mobile devices and some amazing things can come from that. Companies have now began to try and make everything sync so you can have centralized management systems for your everyday life, making it simpler. For example: You can control the room temperature, light intensity, schedule a pickup, and turn on the fireplace before you get home from your romantic date all from your phone.

This inter-connectivity has made a lot of wonderful things possible but remember with great power comes great responsibility. In the wrong hands it can cause a lot of damage. Such was the case with the WannaCry ransomware that held your computer and your files hostage until you paid a certain amount of money in BitCoins. Another case was the hacking of Jeff Bezo’s phone causing him a divorce and billions of dollars lost as a consequence.

The Internet Of Things is something massive that has endless possibilities and in the right hands it can help mankind achieve new heights but we must not forget to also live in the real world. We must not spend our days looking at life through a screen, instead we must use this connectivity and these technologies to boost our interactions in the real world.

>Here are some tips to avoid internet addiction so you don’t end up like those “human” beings in Wall-E.

I hope you have a great day.

S.

items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description:
>Unsplash

This is a subject that will catch everyone’s attention. You will see an occasional Terminator reference, you might think of ‘I Robot’ or that chapter in Rick and Morty where their dog becomes super powerful with mechanic enhancements. But reality is different, in fact, machine learning is a branch of Artificial Intelligence which also gathers deep learning. In this article we will focus on ML (machine learning) but we will also shed some light on it’s brother DL (deep learning) so you can tell the difference.

Let’s get to it!

MACHINE LEARNING

>Unsplash

At its core, machine learning simply refers to the sub-field of artificial intelligence used to analyze and interpret data in order to discover patterns or something else that the programmer desires and it can be used on pretty much any specific field you can think of. To illustrate things better think of the suggestions you get from Netflix for what you might want to watch next, TikTok’s system that will always throw content at you, or heart-rate monitors that analyze your data and give you suggestions such as “It seems you’re stressed. Breathe”. All these applications come from the implementation of different machine learning algorithms that use data to reach a “conclusion” that will result in some previously programmed action. Maybe it’s not what you expected seeing so many sci-fi references but the potential here is limitless and very powerful.

Here, I will give you some of the core concepts that make ML and explain them briefly in bite sized portions.

ML is all about applying math in cool ways so basically there are two main types of machine learning algorithms: supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

Supervised Learning

These algorithms get trained by having a labeled data set fed to it, it needs to be told what to receive and what the result will be for each thing that it receives. A labeled data set is a group of data that contains both the input and the expected output; an example could be a dog training: you say “hand” (the input) the dog now extends its paw towards you (the output).

Such behavior of the supervised learning algorithm means that the more data it receives the better it will get in time. Designed to adjust itself by making predictions on the possible outcomes it is very useful to draw conclusions quickly and help people with their decision making processes like choosing which route to take home at rush hour, analyzing market prices by receiving certain attributes from the goods as input or calculating risk in a business environment where there is precedent that examples can be drawn from. As you may have noticed not all applications explicitly include numbers, how can this be? Well, there are also two main types of supervised learning algorithms to choose from: classification and regression.

items.description: Python Programming 101: Mutable and Immutable Objects

>

There are a few things truer than true in this world: the sun rises in the east and sets in the west, we are here for a finite amount of time and everything is an object in Python. You will find that in the last case the objects we are talking about are very abstract since you cannot grab them with your hands but once you understand the concept behind OOP (Object Oriented Programming) your horizon will expand. This time we are going to focus on a pair of characteristics that objects in Python may have: their mutable and immutable properties which will allow them to morph (or don’t) to what the user wants it to.

First, lets’s take a look at a couple of helpful built-in functions Python has to offer.

ID()

This function will allow the user to see the identity of an object, in C it would be the address. One must only enter the object’s name inside the parentheses and the function will return the ID number. The number the function returns is unique but it may vary depending on the machine you execute it in; for example every citizen has a Social Security number, each one is different and each number will remain unique in a person’s lifetime. But what is this good for? In the event you want to identify if an object has retained its identity after the value has been altered this function can be your ally.

>

TYPE()

The ‘type’ function will allow the user to find out the type of variable that he is handling. There are cases where a program grows bigger than expected and inevitably there will be some confusion among which you can find you forget what type of data you were handling with a given object. The syntax for this function is also very simple it just needs the object’s name inside the parentheses and that’s it, it will return the vartype so you can keep coding.

>

Now that we got that out of the way let’s get to the beefy part of this article:

Mutable Objects

>

Whenever an object is created, inherently there is also a new ID that comes with it. The object now takes space in memory and it is unique like a fingerprint in a newborn child. The mutable characteristic of an object means that it can be freely modified and the ID will stay the same, following the child’s example think that it will grow, maybe get a tattoo and grow a beard but the fingerprint will remain. Among the Python objects that can be modified you will find lists, sets, dictionaries and classes you build.

Above, you can see how a new object called ‘a’ is created, then a list of values is assigned to it; later we replaced one of the values in the list for another one that was not even the same type as the rest and there was no issue with this mod thanks to the mutable properties of a list in Python. The ID was printed to demonstrate that the address in memory has stayed the same even though the object was modified.

Immutable Objects

>

Following the logic behind mutable objects we can now deduct the main idea behind immutable objects: they cannot be modified. Among the objects in Python that cannot be modified you will find integers, floats, strings, unicode and tuples. Unlike the previous property, the object in question will not keep the same ID after the value has been changed due to the fact that the object has to be completely moved to a new space in memory since it cannot be modified where it currently is. For example, in a videogame you could choose a magician as your avatar but if you wanted to make it a soldier you couldn’t just put some gear on it, you would have to change avatars completely.

In this example an object is created that holds a string value, then an attempt to modify the string has landed in an error (because of the immutable property it holds in Python). After this, the value was completely replaced by another one and when the two IDs are compared you can see that they are different, meaning they have taken two different places in memory.

Differences in Handling Process

In Python, accessing an immutable object is a quicker process since it stays the same as when it was first instantiated but when you want to change it the drawback makes an appearance. It will cost more resources from the system due to the fact that it must reserve anew space in memory and remake it. On the other hand, going by the opposites, a mutable object is handled in such a way that it can be harder to process due to it’s ever-changing capacity and quicker to modify since no additional memory space is required.

How do functions handle mutable and immutable objects?

In short, a function can call a variable by value or by reference. The difference between both is that in the first one the variables are copied for whatever purpose you desire and in the second one the ID of the variable is the one passed over. The thing is, to avoid changing the original value of a mutable variable it is better to be passed by reference to the function and the immutable variable can be passed by value safely since it cannot be modified.

Mutable and immutable properties in Python make up for a more organized way of coding; you must first think and figure out the structure of how you will code and implement your program so you can choose what type of objects you will use. Correctly using your objects will result in a more efficient program and who wouldn’t want that?

May your tomorrows be filled with bug-free code!

S.

items.author: Sergio Pietri
items.description:
>

As you may already know, Python is a OOP oriented language, and while you can use it to program procedurally it is best used with the aforementioned programming paradigm. This means that it works best by organizing the data properly and creating classes so the code can be encapsulated and later reused for max efficiency and to avoid repeating unnecessary code blocks. All this can be achieved thanks to the objects and the classes you create along with their attributes and characteristics so let’s take a quick look as to what are some of the differences between them.

Class and Class attributes

A class goes hand in hand with the encapsulation principle of object oriented programming in which each object should be restricted to a certain field of action. A class is that field and the objects are the ones who play in it. Think of the class as a blueprint to build something, the most usual example is a house blueprint.

The blueprint can contain the materials needed to build it, the distribution, the amount of rooms, and the color of the house. You could use one blueprint to build several houses and you could maybe paint them in different colors or change the amount of rooms but the core build of the house will come from that blueprint you have.

This is what happens with classes. You can create a class to build something and then use it as many times as you like to build new things with it and those things can be the objects.

When it comes to the attributes of a class in Python you will find that they refer to variable that belongs to the class and not to a particular object (like inside a method of the class). The attributes are defined outside of any object and before the constructor of the class (identifiable in Python by the __init__ method).

They are shared by all the other objects inside the class like if they were a global variable.

>

The image above shows how we declare a class called ‘ClassDeclared’ that contains an attribute called ‘class_variable’ and is initialized to 0. Later we can find the constructor identified by the __init__ method.

Objects and Object attributes

There’s a lot of talk about objects but what exactly are they? This is an abstract concept since it doesn’t refer specifically to a physical object, but one could say that everything is an object in Python.

An object is a collection of data with a particular objective, it can be a method (known as a function in procedural programming) or a variable.

In Python, you can use classes to create objects of that type, think of it as if you were declaring a variable in C where you declare the variable type with ‘int’ and then you give it a name. Here, you can do something similar with classes.

>

What happend here is that we just created an object called ‘object’ that will contain the atributes and methods contained in ‘ClassDeclared’. Our object will now inherit the class characteristics so if this was a house we would have just created a new house with all the details contained in the blueprint (the class).

Difference Between Object and Class attributes:

The main difference between both, other than the fact that objects and classes share different concepts, is that an object (or instance) attribute refers only to a variable that belongs to an object and is declared inside the __init__ method of your class, most commonly known in other languages as a constructor.

On the other hand, a class attribute is a variable that must be declared outside of any other object (meaning methods in this case) so that it belongs to the class in general; it is almost like a mini global variable that can be initialized with a desired value or character to be used in any method (object) inside the class.

The main advantage that these attributes can have is their ability to be used and reused whenever the programmer desires to do so, meaning less code must be rewritten and not all of it has to be imported. You could simply use certain attributes that work in any specific case for a task that you must develop or use certain methods for precise functionality.

But not everything is rainbows and butterflies, a drawback in this case is that some times it can prove hard to keep track of every class and method you created so everything must be kept neatly organized and with proper notes. Also, but not anything significant, the concept can be harder to grasp due to its abstractness than a procedural type of coding.

Object Oriented Programming can be a tricky concept to handle since it mostly consists of very abstract content, but in practice this is the most effective way to code specially in a team environment. Knowing the difference between instances and classes can help solidify the OOP paradigm in your mind so you can apply it easier in your real-life scenarios and the concepts discussed here are part of that core you must begin to learn.

I hope you have a great day!
